Award.AwardTitle: Evolution of a pheromonal communication system in amphibians
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how organisms communicate with one other and how communication systems arise and change over time is a major challenge in biology. This project provides a rare opportunity to investigate the origin and diversification of a chemical communication system at the molecular level in amphibians (salamanders and frogs). In addition, this research can provide a novel framework for applications in computer science, where current research is focused on building systems that can evolve and use communication to accomplish jobs and then adapt as needs change. The project will also contribute to the training of a postdoctoral researcher and numerous undergraduate students in collaboration with MSU's BEACON Center and an ongoing REU site award.

Specifically, the objectives of this work are to trace the evolutionary link between compounds that amphibians produce in the skin as antimicrobials and their later use as pheromones; to purify and test the efficacy of those compounds as antimicrobials and pheromones; and to identify the molecular mechanism used to smell those compounds. The results will be obtained through the use of bioinformatics and genomics to trace the genetic history of genes, protein biochemistry to isolate and test the gene products, behavioral experiments to determine which compounds function as pheromones, and electrophysiology to identify the neuronal mechanisms responsible for sensing the pheromones. Results from these studies will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and through presentations at scientific conferences. All data will be available upon request and deposited at Dryad and the NCBI Trace archive.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the proposed work was to identify proteins that are used as pheromones – chemicals that provide information about animals to other members of the same species – in axolotls, a type of aquatic salamander that is widely used in research. We planned to identify the proteins that convey information about sex and reproductive status and then synthesize these proteins for use in experiments to examine their behavioral effects as well as the neural mechanisms by which they are detected. Our hope was that this research would provide a model system for understanding the evolution of communication systems, as protein evolution is much easier to study than evolution of more complex signals, like bird songs or the patterns on peacock tails. We characterized several protein pheromones from male axolotls but unfortunately we were not able to synthesize them, as they have complex structures that either were not adequately reproduced (using some methods we tried) or led to tangled clumps of unusable proteins (using another approach). Thus, we were not able to carry out most of our plans. In the course of the project we began to investigate the function of unusual tail movements that male axolotls perform during courtship, which have been thought to disperse pheromones. Our research to date suggests that instead these movements provide mechanical cues, and we will continue to pursue this line of research as a different model for understanding evolution of communication.

In the course of this project we learned that our axolotls were infected with Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis(Bd), a fungal infection that has decimating frog populations worldwide for several decades. Although treatments for Bd in frogs have been widely publicized, treatment protocols for Bd in salamanders had not been described. We collaborated with a campus veterinarian to develop a successful treatment for Bd in axolotls and other salamanders that we study. Our salamanders are now Bd-free and we published the first case study of Bd symptoms and treatment in salamanders as well as detailed protocols to allow others to treat this infection in salamanders.

Undergraduate students played key roles in the project, both helping with the pheromone research (learning to carry out bioinformatic analyses and behavioral experiments) and with developing and implementing protocols for treating Bd in our salamanders. A graduate student earned a Master’s degree for his work developing and analyzing a dataset of proteins expressed in a large pheromone-producing gland in axolotls, and a PhD student was involved in efforts to synthesize the proteins and to learn how they are dispersed. In addition to these research efforts, members of the lab were involved MSU’s “Grandparents University”, teaching mini-courses on taste and smell to grandparents and their grandchildren.
